factoid: Prince Anatole said that if the minister starts a row, Prince Anatole will go away.
Prince Anatole said that he cannot bear those old men.
It was known in maidservants’ rooms that the minister and his son had arrived.
The appearance of the minister and the minister's son had been minutely described.
Princess Mary was sitting alone in her room, vainly trying to master her agitation.
Princess Mary looked at herself in the glass.
Princess Mary wondered how she could enter the drawing room.
Princess Mary said that even if she likes him, she cannot be herself with him.
The mere thought of Princess Mary's father's look filled her with terror.
The little princess and Mademoiselle Bourienne had received from Másha a report describing the minister's son as handsome.
The report described the minister's son as having rosy cheeks and dark eyebrows.
The report described the minister dragging his legs upstairs with difficulty.
The report described the minister's son following the minister like an eagle, three steps at a time.
The little princess and Mademoiselle Bourienne went into Princess Mary's room after receiving the information.
The little princess said to Princess Mary that they had come.
The little princess waddled into the room and sank heavily into an armchair.
Princess Mary was wearing one of her best dresses instead of her usual loose gown.
Princess Mary's hair was carefully done.
Princess Mary's face was animated.
Princess Mary's face had sunken and faded outlines.
Princess Mary was dressed as she used to be in Petersburg society.
Princess Mary's appearance had become plainer.
An unobtrusive touch was added to Mademoiselle Bourienne's toilette, making her face fresh and pretty.
Mademoiselle Bourienne asked Princess Mary if she would remain as she is.
Mademoiselle Bourienne said that the gentlemen are in the drawing room and they would have to go down.
Mademoiselle Bourienne said that Princess Mary had not smartened herself up.
The little princess devised and carried out a plan to dress Princess Mary.
Princess Mary's self-esteem was wounded by the arrival of a suitor.
The arrival of a suitor agitated Princess Mary.
Princess Mary's companions did not conceive that the situation could be otherwise.
Princess Mary considered telling her companions she felt ashamed would betray her agitation.
Princess Mary considered that declining their offers to dress her would prolong their banter and insistence.
Princess Mary flushed, her beautiful eyes grew dim, red blotches appeared on her face, and she took on an unattractive martyrlike expression.
Princess Mary submitted herself to Mademoiselle Bourienne and Lise.
Mademoiselle Bourienne and Lise tried sincerely to make Princess Mary look pretty.
Princess Mary was so plain that Mademoiselle Bourienne and Lise could not consider her a rival.
Mademoiselle Bourienne and Lise began dressing Princess Mary with perfect sincerity.
Mademoiselle Bourienne and Lise believed that dress can make a face pretty.
Lise said that the dress was not pretty.
Lise looked sideways at Princess Mary from a little distance.
Lise told Princess Mary to fetch her maroon dress.
Lise warned Princess Mary that her whole life could be at stake.
Lise said that the dress was too light and not becoming.
The face and figure of Princess Mary were not pretty.
Mademoiselle Bourienne and the little princess believed that adding a blue ribbon, combing hair up, and arranging a blue scarf on the maroon dress would make everything well.
Mademoiselle Bourienne and the little princess forgot that Princess Mary's frightened face and figure could not be altered.
Mademoiselle Bourienne and the little princess believed that changing the setting and adornment would still leave the face piteous and plain.
Princess Mary submitted to two or three changes.
Princess Mary's hair had been arranged on top of her head.
Princess Mary wore a maroon dress with a pale-blue scarf.
The little princess walked twice around Princess Mary, adjusting a fold of the dress with her hand.
The little princess arranged the scarf and looked at Princess Mary with her head bent first on one side and then on the other.
